Description: Mould-made scarab in Egyptian blue; back rubbed, with outline of clypeus and prothorax just marked and elytra division faintly visible; at side, legs simply modelled, with undercut triangle; underside deeply incised with representation of two animals, arranged one above the other: couchant lion in upper field, grazing deer in lower field; longitudinally pierced under projecting elements of carapace; in hard paste, grainy in texture and bright blue in colour; base chipped and eroded surface.
Curator's comments: Lion attacking a prey is a recurrent theme on Egyptian blue scarabs and scaraboids produced at the “Scarab Factory” (on its various productions, see Webb forthcoming). This scarab belongs to a type which was widely distributed in the Mediterranean area, particularly in Eastern Greece, and Southern Russia (Gorton 1996, 121-127, type XXXIV, subtype B1-17, see especially B15 for this piece). This group varies in style with other animal representations on Naukratite scarabs and scaraboids - animals with more elongated bodies, finer incisions - giving the impression that they are of better workmanship (Gorton 1996, 122). This type of representation can be paralleled to Archaic Greek gems, with single oval line incised round edge. Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Petrie, W.M.F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884–5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Webb, V. forthcoming, Faience finds from Naukratis and their implication for the chronology of the site, in R. Thomas (ed.) forthcoming. Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum 16th – 17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXVII, no. 137)
Gorton 1996 / Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites (p. 123-124, type XXXIV B15)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OE.10) (phase 3)
